message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of bilateral lower extremity swelling after starting a new medication suggests that it is most likely a calcium channel blocker, which can cause peripheral edema as a side effect. Inhibition of hormone receptor is unlikely to cause such symptoms. Potassium-sparing diuretics may prevent edema but not cause it, and potassium-wasting diuretics can actually worsen edema.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has bilateral lower extremity swelling and is on medication for blood pressure, suggesting the most likely drug is a calcium channel blocker. Calcium channel blockers are known to cause peripheral edema as a side effect. Option B, inhibition of hormone receptor, does not fit the scenario. Option C, potassium-sparing diuretic, actually helps treat edema, while option D, potassium-wasting diuretic, can cause electrolyte imbalances but does not directly cause peripheral edema.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient was recently started on a medication for her blood pressure, which suggests that the medication is likely an antihypertensive. Among the options, only calcium channel blockers are known to cause edema as a side effect, leading to bilateral lower extremity swelling. Therefore, the most likely mechanism of action for the drug prescribed to this patient is inhibition of calcium channels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has bilateral lower extremity swelling which is a common side effect of calcium channel blockers, which are used to treat hypertension by inhibiting calcium channels. Option (C) is unlikely because potassium-sparing diuretics do not typically cause swelling, and option (D) is unlikely because potassium-wasting diuretics actually help decrease swelling. Option (B) is not specific enough as there are numerous types of hormone receptors and inhibitors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest peripheral edema, which is a side effect of calcium channel blockers often prescribed for hypertension. Inhibition of hormone receptors is more commonly seen in medications for cancer treatment. Potassium-sparing diuretics would not cause peripheral edema, while potassium-wasting diuretics would actually reduce edema.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing bilateral lower extremity swelling, which indicates edema. Among the options, only inhibitors of calcium channels can cause edema as a side effect. This is likely due to the medication causing peripheral vasodilation, leading to fluid accumulation in the tissue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has bilateral lower extremity swelling, which is a common side effect of calcium channel blockers, a type of antihypertensive medication. Calcium channel blockers work by inhibiting calcium channels, which results in vasodilation and decreased blood pressure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has bilateral lower extremity swelling, which suggests edema. The most likely mechanism of action for the drug prescribed is inhibition of calcium channels, which can lead to fluid accumulation and edema. Potassium-sparing diuretics can actually prevent edema, while potassium-wasting diuretics can cause it. Inhibition of hormone receptors is a less likely mechanism in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has bilateral lower extremity swelling and was started on a new medication for hypertension. Among the options, only inhibition of calcium channels can cause fluid retention and edema, leading to lower extremity swelling.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation suggests edema, which is a common side effect of some blood pressure medications. Inhibition of calcium channels is the mechanism of action for calcium channel blockers, which are used to treat hypertension and can cause edema as a side effect. Inhibition of hormone receptors is the mechanism of action for hormone therapies, not blood pressure medications. Potassium-sparing diuretics can actually decrease edema, while potassium-wasting diuretics can cause it.
